channel.title: A-Frame
channel.description: A web framework for building virtual reality experiences. Make WebVR with HTML and Entity-Component. Works on Vive, Rift, desktop, mobile platforms.

item.title: Image Tracking and Location-Based AR with A-Frame and AR.js 3
item.description:
We’re happy to announce AR.js 3 and A-Frame integration featuring new image and location based tracking.

For detailed API reference and source code check the official documentation and the Github repository
item.content:encoded:
We’re happy to announce AR.js 3 and A-Frame integration featuring new image and location based tracking.

For detailed API reference and source code check the official documentation and the Github repository

Getting Started with Image Tracking

The new AR.js tracking can take any arbitrary image or drawing (not only markers) to position and display your 3D content.

You just need a high resolution image with a good amount of detail. The more complexity in the image the better the tracking. Learn how to choose images for best results in this article by Daniel Fernandes.

For this tutorial we will use the following image:

Creating Image Descriptors

Next step is to create image descriptors: a set of files that describe your image and are needed by the tracking algorithm. We will use the NFT Marked creator available via Web (also available locally as a node.js script if you prefer). Upload your image and click “generate” to create the descriptors. Once the image is processed three files will automatically download. Copy the following snippet of code on a new HTML file and host it on a server. Also a Codepen with all the necessary code is available below for convenience.

Point <path-to-your-image-descriptors> to the path containing the Image Descriptors you generated and downloaded before. Those files will have a common name. Remove the file extension (e.g. with “dinosaur.fset”, “dinosaur.iset” and so on, the path you have to add should end with “dinosaur”).

Serve the example from a local or remote server: Github Pages and Glitch are free and convenient options. Navigate to the URL on your device and you should see a T-Rex model after the loading screen disappears.

Visit this Codepen if you want to see right away how it looks without hosting your own.

You can replace the model above with any other assets: 2D videos, images, audio files. Any A-Frame a-entity is a valid child of the a-nft anchor.

Location-Based AR

Location-based tracking uses real-world coordinates to place AR content in context. Users can move freely (outdoors for better precision) and content associated with their location will be scaled and placed accordingly (e.g: content will render bigger / smaller based on distance to the user). With AR.js and A-Frame is now very easy to build experiences like cities and museum tours, restaurant guides, treasure hunts, biology or history learning games or place virtual art on any real world location.

The following example shows how to place text on a fixed position in the real world. The text will remain in place as you move around. The content is anchored to your current location. Make sure that GPS tracking is enabled on your device before you try.

Some notes:

  • Replace <add-your-latitude> and <add-your-longitude> with your GPS coordinates. There are several online services that lets you retrieve those data for free like latlong
  • Change the scale property according to the distance of the place you specified with the coordinates: if you are not seeing the text, try to scale it up or choose a place much near
  • We used the custom look-at A-Frame component, that makes the content always look towards the user camera. This is fundamental, in particular for 2D content as text.

Run the example on your device with GPS data on and you should be able to see the text fixed in place. Its position should honor the real-world positioning according to the GPS coordinates you added.

Unleash your creativity and replace the text with any content you like, thanks to A-Frame you can quickly display 3D models, videos, images: Any a-entity will be tracked as expected..

You can find additional support on the resources linked below and also on the official Gitter channel.

Have fun and please share the AR experiences you built with AR.js and A-Frame. We will love to check them out!

Nicolo Carpignoli and Diego Marcos.

Additional Resources

  • AR.js Repository
  • AR.js Documentation
  • Location-based Tutorials with AR.js

item.title: Experiment with AR and A-Frame
item.description:
Google Chrome and Oculus Browser are now shipping WebXR enabled by default for VR headsets. The Web magic doesn’t stop there. AR is also coming to the standard and you can experiment today on ARCore compatible devices and Chrome 79 or newer.

Enable the experimental WebXR AR module in chrome://flags and make sure your page is served over HTTPS. A-Frame 1.0.3 or newer automatically detects AR and shows the new Enter AR button:
item.content:encoded:
Google Chrome and Oculus Browser are now shipping WebXR enabled by default for VR headsets. The Web magic doesn’t stop there. AR is also coming to the standard and you can experiment today on ARCore compatible devices and Chrome 79 or newer.

Enable the experimental WebXR AR module in chrome://flags and make sure your page is served over HTTPS. A-Frame 1.0.3 or newer automatically detects AR and shows the new Enter AR button:

Build a scene in the same way than you do for VR. Just make sure that the background doesn’t block the camera view 🙂

Try now on your ARCore phone and check out the source code

What about interactions?

When entering immersive mode, regular user DOM Events are disabled. There are two ongoing efforts to enable interactivity in AR experiences:

Hit Test

Developers will be able to cast rays into the real world and retrieve a list of intersection points against the real world understanding. A ray might be triggered by user input like touches or mouse clicks to for instance, place or move virtual objects in the real world.

DOM Overlay layer

When entering AR or VR mode, only WebGL content and the real world or camera image are rendered on screen. DOM layers will allow overlaying HTML elements to present for instance 2D UIs, instructions or contextual information associated to virtual or real world objects.

Join our discord channel. The community will love to see what you make.

If you’d like to continue to support us, please subscribe to the A-Frame newsletter where we’ll not only provide updates and showcase community projects, but requests for testing and user feedback support every now and then to keep us going in this grassroots project.

item.title: A-Frame v1.0.0 - WebXR Support, AR Mode
item.description:
Today marks A-Frame’s fourth birthday. Four years ago, on December 16th, 2015, we released the first version of A-Frame to make it easier to build VR experiences and make the Web keep pace with the VR industry.

With the help of a community of hundreds of thousands of developers over the years, we’re releasing A-Frame v1.0.0 to support the coming out of the WebXR spec which has been under discussion for the past several years. The upgrade to A-Frame v1 and beyond will become necessary on more and more browsers as they deprecate WebVR and only support the WebXR specification.

To clear confusion, WebXR refers to both AR and VR support on the Web. To that end, we’ve included an AR mode out of the box in A-Frame for browsers that support ARCore and ARKit. In production, make sure to use HTTPS for VR and AR support.

We’d like to thank in part Google for providing a bit of funding to us at Supermedium to help develop and maintain WebXR support for A-Frame. And to thank people within Google, Oculus, and importantly the Web community for testing this version for us. We’ll continue to provide necessary updates to A-Frame.

We’d also like to celebrate now 300+ contributors, 10,000+ GitHub stars, and 300+ email subscribers to the A-Frame project.

If you’d like to continue to support us, please subscribe to the A-Frame newsletter where we’ll not only provide updates and showcase community projects, but requests for testing and user feedback support every now and then to keep us going in this grassroots project.

Read the release notes and changelog.

A-Frame 1.0.0 is out! 🥳 With full WebXR support shipping now in Chrome 79 and Oculus Browser stable channels. Deliver VR experiences instantaneously to millions of users today! Happy immersive Christmas! 🎄

— A-Frame (@aframevr) December 16, 2019

We're still at it! Today marks the exact date of @aframevr's fourth birthday, and we're excited to release v1 with the help of the #WebVR community. https://t.co/rlvFSpjBvu https://t.co/DHgRoEgb9f

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) December 16, 2019

For those who are using AR.js with #aframe in WebAR apps, please import latest #aframe, v1.0.0 has been shipped 🚀

This will avoid problems with new Chrome 79 that has WebXR Device API enabled by default.

Thanks to @aframevr team for the great work. It's outstanding.

— Nicolò Carpignoli (@nicolocarp) <a href=”

For those who are using AR.js with #aframe in WebAR apps, please import latest #aframe, v1.0.0 has been shipped 🚀

This will avoid problems with new Chrome 79 that has WebXR Device API enabled by default.

Thanks to @aframevr team for the great work. It's outstanding.

— Nicolò Carpignoli (@nicolocarp) December 15, 2019
?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw”>December 15, 2019

Hey devs! 👋 Remember to serve your content over HTTPS to enter VR mode in Chrome with A-Frame 1.0.0. WebXR is not available over HTTP.

— A-Frame (@aframevr) December 16, 2019

🎉I'm SUPER excited for the 1.0.0 release of @aframevr now that #WebXR is shipping in Chrome 79🎉
There's SO much potential of merging spatial computing with the open web to form the #widerweb & early seeds for what may become "The Metaverse."
Congrats to the @supermediumvr team! https://t.co/FuEgbBstFS

— Kent Bye VoicesOfVR (@kentbye) December 16, 2019

item.title: A-Frame Newsletter 1
item.description:
The return of the A-Frame roundups! Thank you for subscribing to the email newsletter if you have! If you have not already, subscribe through aframe.io/subscribe.

A-Frame v1 with WebXR and AR support will be releasing shortly as the industry-wide rollout of WebXR commences. Everything is ready to go after a bit more testing. After years of work, we’re excited to be ready for the wave on day 1.

And we’re excited to release Night Sky, a VR planetarium built with A-Frame to look and learn about the stars! You can set your location and see constellations above you in real time.

Without further ado, check out cool A-Frame projects from the recent months.

Built a huge 5ft Gameboy you can fully play in Web VR - https://t.co/RxkwFVwtPO - open source & made with @aframevr @dmarcos @Tojiro pic.twitter.com/nUsdLOqLTd

— Tal Kol (@koltal) December 6, 2019

Built Flappy Birds VR with @aframevr ! WebVR is awesome. Warning, game is intense - https://t.co/Z1b4fqoX9E pic.twitter.com/fCGvYcWEq2

— Tal Kol (@koltal) November 20, 2019

A demo of the different modes and opportunities to workout with Towermax Fitness Drill Track.
The length of running you see is 6 meters, in VR it's 12 meters with the room extender.
Full Video here:https://t.co/dHF3bsg4E2#vrfitness #OculusQuest #webxr #runningmotivation pic.twitter.com/UtukWV5zAe

— TowermaxFitness (@towermaxfitness) November 19, 2019

— Sumi Senthi (@SumiSenthi) October 20, 2019

You can try it out here: https://t.co/xpS5mIwia2
Made with @aframevr and #threejs #VR #music #instrument pic.twitter.com/uRfsoS3QUY

— Oliver Fei (@OliverFei_VR) November 26, 2019

Done and submitted. Here's a clip of yesterdays stream playing the finished the @aframevr #webxr game build for the #js13k competition. It's intense… pic.twitter.com/xENSMiSgLA

— É¬Ä±É±É±á§ ÆÆ¡ÆÆÉ ð· (@Sorskoot) September 13, 2019

You can now play Cadenza!! here: https://t.co/wDzrUnvRtW

— J-ROM (@herebefrogs) September 10, 2019

— J-ROM (@herebefrogs) September 9, 2019

item.title: A Week of A-Frame 170 - 172
item.description:
OculusQuestのコントローラーの座標とアクションを読み取って、動的にアニメーション生成するVRできたーーー！JavaScript初心者すぎて、めちゃくちゃ苦労したけど、丸一日頑張ったらなんとかなったー！やったー！#OculusQuest #aframevr pic.twitter.com/buT2gLRNVK

— 零 (@shadow_burst) June 23, 2019

Messing about with client side per-vertex AO baking in @aframevr, over the top right now, but cheap & easy 😉 Props to #threejs, @mrdoob & @aframevr team 👍. I had to code next to nothing myself, octree for raytracing in <80 lines…mind blown🤯#webxr #webvr pic.twitter.com/MVh55Ytj8w

— Paul Brunt (@super_eggbert) July 11, 2019

A new component for aframevr that allows you to include normal html and css in your scene. Plus, it allows for direct manipulation and interaction from inside aframe, so you can quickly build UI using simple html and css. https://t.co/wLD0WrzJSM@aframevr #vr #webxr #webvr pic.twitter.com/ME4LkwN0aH

— Paul Brunt (@super_eggbert) June 30, 2019

VR portfolio in Oculus Quest with A-Frame https://t.co/SfnT5ZX2wl #aframevr pic.twitter.com/rWKV2kTziH

— だら🍔技術系投稿サービス運営中 (@dala00) July 5, 2019

"The Journey To My New #WebVR Website" 🚀
( series of steps before bringing it to life ) 👣

3. "Come To Daddy" 🎣@aframevr #TheJourneyToMyNewWebVRWebsite#WebXR #VR #UXofVR #Immersive #WebDesign pic.twitter.com/OYCqiGvgns

— Danilo Pasquariello (@theDart76) July 5, 2019

VR radio controled car with stick. (also wasd control is available for pc browser) https://t.co/EqJo4jW7IJ #oculusquest #oculusquestdev #aframevr pic.twitter.com/0pm7MBXYx4

— だら🍔技術系投稿サービス運営中 (@dala00) June 22, 2019

From paper to #XR (or just 3D) on the web in a couple of steps! https://t.co/6RdM4BM1wh

How does it work?
- hand 📝draw on a @Moleskine Pen+ Ellipse
- export SVG and upload online
- extrude the SVG in @AFrameVR (using @luiguild component https://t.co/TWkBMI1tyA )

…that's it! pic.twitter.com/DJfODq3XJH

— Thomas Wang (@thomaswangio) May 12, 2019

We've created the first ever online 3D #kitchentour which not only works in a browser on any device but also on VR headsets too. Take a look at the project in full and explore here> https://t.co/2g6QgAqCA8#VR #VirtualReality #WebGL @aframevr #interactive #archviz #interiordesign pic.twitter.com/owaWhyMy8N

— Ukaton (@ConcreteSciFi) May 28, 2019

I've updated my Epic Medieval Battle to @aframevr v0.9.2! 🚀

Featured: https://t.co/kR78L9r8cD
Direct link: https://t.co/qlZmZ5MHp5#OculusQuest #OculusRift #HTCVive pic.twitter.com/V9aTW5Vjq4

— Danilo Pasquariello (@theDart76) June 5, 2019

Point cloud viewer worked well on WebVR framework. #OculusQuest #OculusQuestDev #webvr #aframevr https://t.co/tL8102bid7

— T_Yoshinaga (@Tks_Yoshinaga) June 3, 2019

#vrlandio runs with 65-70fps with @aframevr on #Oculus #OculusGo pic.twitter.com/jacsd0st8n

— arpu (@arnputz) June 3, 2019

Hey all, proud to announce I finished my demo Virtual Reality Art Gallery UI in WebVR using A-frame. Anyone interested in an innovative "VR/AR Start-up" contact me! https://t.co/Ka58XraW2w #aframevr #webvr #virtualreality @aframevr #art #artists #artgallery #webxr #OculusQuest pic.twitter.com/rRQlP17Psd

— Michael McAnally (@Michael_Blade) June 2, 2019

本日の進捗です。ブロックに当たり判定つけて、登れるようになりました。#oculusquest #oculusquestdev #福岡XR部 #aframevr pic.twitter.com/81i1dTuPLF

The early makings of a game? @aframevr work in progress. pic.twitter.com/g575dUYqA2

— Timothy Dang (@supatimbo) May 21, 2019

Still appreciating and using the small Fader teasers @MaxKoschyk did for us ages ago for test purposes - btw screenshot contains a teaser to a new upcoming feature -> https://t.co/aRKgruJQik#go3d #immersive #360 #madewithaframe@vragments, @Journalism_360, @aframevr pic.twitter.com/mqrxNUj2kx

— Stephan Gensch (@HelrenPDM) June 14, 2019

I just published my first @aframevr and @the8thwall demo demonstrating what the Tokyo Olympics 2020 ticket might look like if it was #AR enabled. https://t.co/lX6vJh4cGW It's so cool taking what I know from A-Frame and WebVR and using the 8th Wall API to make web-based AR.

— Yoni Binstock (@YoniBinstock) June 17, 2019

Glitch collection with the simple projects I used this morning in our introductory workshop to @aframevr https://t.co/BlvqiQTDrF Quite simple, using just a single #HTML document for #virtualreality and #augmentedreality scenes pic.twitter.com/RHFyURcRjH

— Jesus M Gonzalez-Barahona (@jgbarah) June 13, 2019

You think you're work is hot? Check out @usnistgov work by Matt Hoehler (and partners) highlighted in @sciam article "Watch a Raging Forest Fire Surround You in 360 Degrees" https://t.co/1RWUoPCtNs
See @aframevr version at: https://t.co/KDokQpKoXA

— Sandy Ressler (@sressler) June 13, 2019

so appreciative of @andgokevin and @dmarcos for @aframevr, state component, example projects, etc! Very creative platform! Here is WIP for UI for upcoming project. (Pretend that Kevin's list of weather cities is instead multiple "games" for the platform that can be loaded) pic.twitter.com/7T0ejVRqJ6

— Kieran Farr (@kfarr) June 12, 2019

Watching the Langton's ant generating patterns is amazing!
Even better in #VR thanks to @aframevr

Check it out!https://t.co/dKH02sMLdF#TuringComplete #LangtonsAnt #Aframe pic.twitter.com/RzOkx8XIyy

— Kartik Arora (@karx_brb) June 20, 2019

CS1 IDE for building 3D VR multiplayer games @glitch! The CS1 Game Engine is built with @aframevr.https://t.co/b6UCuRXw7C pic.twitter.com/eMJn0fOQHA

— SirFizX (@SirFizX_ELHS) June 20, 2019

#VR makes 3D content creation very natural: move your hands, create volumes. But when you remove the headset, they do not exist any more.

Now you can 3D print them : @AFrameVR #STL Exporter component https://t.co/u9FDwjRqa0 by Hassadee Pimsuwan (images as concept illustration) pic.twitter.com/F4uMdLCrMF

— Fabien Benetou (@utopiah) June 20, 2019

Build your own @aframevr 3D VR multiplayer project while being guided through focused lessons using the new CS1 IDE! We're far from finished, but definitely out of the gates! 🦄

Remix the project @glitch !https://t.co/b6UCuRXw7Chttps://t.co/ha2GeBsrEi

— SirFizX (@SirFizX_ELHS) June 19, 2019

So you can now update an @aframevr scene asymmetrically with AJAX. Working on handling arbitrary code snippets from a database (to which you can send more code loads though a form). Yep, it's a #holodeck‼️ 😊 pic.twitter.com/O6IladeOXI

— Guillem Carbonell (@ubikretail) June 19, 2019

Components

Published a render-order component for @aframevr. A-Frame defaults to transparency render order based on order of objects added to scene. The render-order component sets it to sort based on Z but also allow defining manual ordering sort of like z-index. https://t.co/rkaQ37P8Fv

— Kevin Ngo (@andgokevin) May 16, 2019

A-Frame Charts Component https://t.co/0sInJtV87r Have #vr visualizations for JSON data in a matter of minutes! Of course, with the help of @aframevr pic.twitter.com/vEj0z4QpMB

— Jesus M Gonzalez-Barahona (@jgbarah) May 15, 2019

Started a @aframevr component.https://t.co/uWmA3TnLJD

— Saké Toshi (@_saketoshi) May 21, 2019

A-Frame Physics System v4 is available – Thanks to @infinite_lee for the big contribution in this release: AmmoJS support!https://t.co/yy7iNpM48m

// @aframevr #webvr #threejs #webgl pic.twitter.com/Pp4B5m1zAi

— Don McCurdy (@donrmccurdy) June 11, 2019

@aframevr STL Exporter component v0.0.2

GitHub: https://t.co/vQ023YGWC8
NPM: https://t.co/ZrWMub85Bc

Note: A lot of things need to improve and optimize, this is the MVP version, not even minify it yet. (tested with #aframe v0.9.2)#threejs #stl #exporter #binary #ascii

— Hassadee (@hassavanich) June 20, 2019

Articles

Most functionality now present for @aframevr user interface guide. Haven't polished the design. But features a menu, list rendering, pagination, XHRs to fetch weather, and binding state to the application. https://t.co/C6AtyIBaDd pic.twitter.com/4pbPfgPPEo

— Kevin Ngo (@andgokevin) May 16, 2019

Events

An awesome evening demoing #webxr annotation using @aframevr with @HatsumiVR at the @FuseBoxBtn pic.twitter.com/qnMJX2u7a0

— Edward Silverton (@edsilv) May 23, 2019

@dmarcos creator of @aframevr showed some cool demos of WebXR. @supermediumvr #webxr pic.twitter.com/d5lFaQGuWt

— Suyash Joshi 🎩 (@suyashcjoshi) May 25, 2019

Challenge for our 2nd #WebVR workshop at @CodeClanScot: master parent and child entities in @aframevr while respecting actual scale! 📐
The goal? To learn the importance of units in #VR and how to take advantage of the origin point when using relative transformations.🤓
#WXRWS pic.twitter.com/UXITG3vmdQ

— Danilo Pasquariello (@theDart76) May 24, 2019

HUGE thanks to @CodeClanScot for making their venue available yesterday! 🙏@TheHappyLass and I talked about portable #VR headsets, consumer adoption, and the versatility of @aframevr to create #WebVR experiences or simply to deliver #3D content in Desktop mode.#WXRWS #WomenInXR pic.twitter.com/kknjRWpNPn

— Danilo Pasquariello (@theDart76) May 24, 2019

Such a great experience running my 1st #WebVR workshop in Abu Dhabi for some @NYUAbuDhabi students yesterday! 👨‍💻👩‍💻👨‍💻👩‍💻
It's not easy to make sure everyone can follow when you're not there physically but eventually the event was a success! 🤓🎉@aframevr #Education #RemoteLearning pic.twitter.com/3AkUEDuxym

— Danilo Pasquariello (@theDart76) June 4, 2019

Loved the experience and the outcome of my 2nd #WebVR workshop for the @NYUAbuDhabi University! 👨‍💻👩‍💻👨‍💻👩‍💻
I like the challenges that come with you not being physically there! 💻
Grateful for the opportunity 🙏 Proud to spread the @aframevr word! 🚀#Education #RemoteLearning #VR pic.twitter.com/pFgV593Dgt

— Danilo Pasquariello (@theDart76) June 17, 2019

Miscellaneous

@aframevr now has super robust in-vr navigation in @Oculus browser for Quest and Go thanks to @abolgar Explore worlds seamlessly! 🌍 https://t.co/CS6qbngWCX

— Diego (@dmarcos) June 7, 2019

How to fix @aframevr breaking iOS 12.1 update? Enable « Motion & Orientation Accès » in Settings > Safari > Privacy & Security.

Alternatively try @mozillareality #WebXR Viewer! https://t.co/oo8CYnmC4K pic.twitter.com/1mOnMPIOoh

— Fabien Benetou (@utopiah) May 13, 2019

@aframevr fam. Remember that devicemotion is now disabled in Safari / Chrome in both iOS and Android. For cardboard mode, user has to enable the API in settings and content has to be served over https. More info https://t.co/Sf8IlfTaS7

— Diego (@dmarcos) May 16, 2019

Awesome collection of @aframevr beginner demos from the community! https://t.co/QkkS3z8lJo most have visible and even editable source code thanks to @glitch and @jsfiddle

— Kieran Farr (@kfarr) June 14, 2019

Just discovered #WebVr and looking forward to getting my feet wet @aframevr @aframevr @TELCAVC https://t.co/ArWNEMYWql https://t.co/yPjQznfyZH

— Lee Campbell (@RealityMixer) June 13, 2019

Thanks @andgokevin for accepting my PR for updated broadcast component for @aframevr ! https://t.co/UhivqNMyiw Come see what it's used for this week at the @GrayAreaorg interactive art showcase: https://t.co/s8ULifPzqb

— Kieran Farr (@kfarr) June 18, 2019

As someone who hasn't really touched VR in over a year, it's great to see how the industry has progressed.

A clear standout thus far? The in-browser impressiveness that is:https://t.co/XBlQE4SDNw

Incredible tech, leveraging a passionate community. And free?! Well played!

— Kevin Pereira (@Attack) May 23, 2019

item.title: A Week of A-Frame 162 + 163
item.description:
We've released @aframevr v0️⃣.9️⃣.1️⃣! Follow up fixes and improvements to 0.9.0 such as WebXR compatibility and browser updates, new component events API, and improved animation performance. https://t.co/bFF0mUVZho

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) April 25, 2019

🔧 We've released @aframevr v0.9.2 with fixes and improvements around link traversal and auto-entering VR where supported (e.g., @supermediumvr). Thanks to @sromline @towermaxfitness for reporting the issue and helping us track it down! https://t.co/MKVUkvyX1H

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 7, 2019

🔷 What will be the equivalent of the Hugo Award for VR? Come catch a glimpse with Blue Cyber, a science fantasy VR series. You are charged to protect the galaxy, given the powers from a mysterious artifact. Experience episode 1, now playing on @supermediumvr. pic.twitter.com/RbpqA1VN8G

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 3, 2019

👾 A multi-legged procedural creature swirls around you. Does it want to play? Built with @aframevr by @snayyss and @kif11. Visit Monster or Friend in @supermediumvr. pic.twitter.com/mC1m2jB4Xo

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 8, 2019
item.content:encoded:
We've released @aframevr v0️⃣.9️⃣.1️⃣! Follow up fixes and improvements to 0.9.0 such as WebXR compatibility and browser updates, new component events API, and improved animation performance. https://t.co/bFF0mUVZho

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) April 25, 2019

🔧 We've released @aframevr v0.9.2 with fixes and improvements around link traversal and auto-entering VR where supported (e.g., @supermediumvr). Thanks to @sromline @towermaxfitness for reporting the issue and helping us track it down! https://t.co/MKVUkvyX1H

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 7, 2019

🔷 What will be the equivalent of the Hugo Award for VR? Come catch a glimpse with Blue Cyber, a science fantasy VR series. You are charged to protect the galaxy, given the powers from a mysterious artifact. Experience episode 1, now playing on @supermediumvr. pic.twitter.com/RbpqA1VN8G

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 3, 2019

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 8, 2019

  • dotrow component

Articles

Like 15% done, but working on an @aframevr guide for building user interfaces. Will include using slice9, layout, raycaster, state components for building menus that dynamically affect the application, hand-attached menus, pagination, XHRs, texture atlas. https://t.co/FOiuaY43wq pic.twitter.com/bYmg3EytpT

— Kevin Ngo (@andgokevin) May 10, 2019

Events

Highly recommend this amazing free workshop organised by @theDart76 and @TheHappyLass. Learn how to make #webVR with @aframevr . No previous coding experience required, such a great way to learn web & 3D skills in a fun and welcoming environment. https://t.co/KunBLpNY7W

— Ryan McKenna (@ryanwmckenna) May 4, 2019

I will be giving talk on @mozillareality & @aframevr in Devtalks Romania on 16th may next week plz join me there and explore the new world of virtual reality and collect some unique swags from @mozilla @mozillareps @mozTechSpeakers @mozillafestival #MozillaVR #WebVR #Aframe https://t.co/ae9skFka0h

— Viral Parmar (@viralparmarhack) May 9, 2019

Trying to search for Peter Rubin's book while listening to @JesseDamiani's #TechTock in @AltspaceVR; but got distracted creating some VR in VR w/ @aframevr. Unfortunately I lost the controls in the ground so sorry to anyone's view I blocked trying to remove it :) pic.twitter.com/DC2W1HqtJe

@technobotanist kicking off @ncsulibraries series of workshops at @Moogfest with a VR picnic in @aframevr pic.twitter.com/19EnBnBUts

HUGE thanks to @TheHappyLass for helping me organise this event!
Bring your friends, we look forward to seeing you there! 👨‍💻👩‍💻👨‍💻👩‍💻@aframevr #WXRWS #WebXR #VR #WomenInXR #WorldChangingGlasgow pic.twitter.com/lwLAslCHGH

— Construct Arcade (@ConstructArcade) April 12, 2019

Our final demo, so far ;)

-Nerly pic.twitter.com/uJRM7iavvQ

— BumbleBee_Studios (@BumblBeeStudios) April 10, 2019

We've released @aframevr v0️⃣.9️⃣.1️⃣! Follow up fixes and improvements to 0.9.0 such as WebXR compatibility and browser updates, new component events API, and improved animation performance. https://t.co/bFF0mUVZho

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) April 25, 2019

♨️ If there was an @aframevr boilerplate I'd recommend, it'd be this one featuring Hot Reloading (change code = auto update scene), HTML requires, and templating. Try it out. https://t.co/XIGDSi6vc3

— Kevin Ngo (@andgokevin) April 12, 2019

Component .events API landed in @aframevr to register event handlers that bind/detach/attach themselves depending on entity/scene state. Improves hot reload experience. https://t.co/yhoUE1qqLu

events: {
click: function (evt) {
this.el.object3D.scale.set(2, 2, 2);
}
}

— Kevin Ngo (@andgokevin) April 12, 2019

item.title: A Week of A-Frame 157 + 158
item.description:
I got a #WebVR terminal emulator working on my phone using @aframevr and Google Daydream on Android.

Now I can do CLI based development from anywhere. 🤯

Gonna slowly work on a fancy mobile VR development environment.https://t.co/NHxqMGwxmp

— Mauve 🎉 (@RangerMauve) April 3, 2019

Visual timeline editor for #WebXR animations. Proof of concept motivated by https://t.co/wImtVnWfL1 relying on @AFrameVR and vis.js (cf https://t.co/zaD1rBMC8H ) pic.twitter.com/m3uI8UpTLe

— Fabien Benetou (@utopiah) March 26, 2019

Making a really wild scene out of torus knots placed in concentric rings using @aframevr! All these shots are from the inspector, which is really great for getting insight & new perspective on a scene! pic.twitter.com/CDEBTm7j3o

— cwervo @ home lol (@acwervo) March 27, 2019

item.title: A-Frame v0.9.0 - Perf & Initial WebXR
item.description:
Over the last year, we’ve continued to try to push the limits of the Web to produce VR content that stands on its own alongside the native apps and games found on the stores. At Supermedium, we developed content such as Soundboxing WebVR alongside @ericflo, Supercraft, and the BeatSaver Viewer.

We’re starting to highlight usage of A-Frame by companies such as Disney, Ford, Toyota, Chevrolet, Sony, Samsung, Google, CERN, Magic Leap, Electronic Frontier Foundation, NPR, and NASA. See the new and developing A-Frame showcase on the website.

And thanks to Google Creative Labs for financially supporting development of initial WebXR support through us at Supermedium in this release of A-Frame.
item.content:encoded:
Over the last year, we’ve continued to try to push the limits of the Web to produce VR content that stands on its own alongside the native apps and games found on the stores. At Supermedium, we developed content such as Soundboxing WebVR alongside @ericflo, Supercraft, and the BeatSaver Viewer.

We’re starting to highlight usage of A-Frame by companies such as Disney, Ford, Toyota, Chevrolet, Sony, Samsung, Google, CERN, Magic Leap, Electronic Frontier Foundation, NPR, and NASA. See the new and developing A-Frame showcase on the website.

And thanks to Google Creative Labs for financially supporting development of initial WebXR support through us at Supermedium in this release of A-Frame.

What’s New?

Major changes to A-Frame involve large performance improvements, a new animation component, Inspector updates, addition of oculus-go-controls + vive-focus-controls, and introductory WebXR support. Note that the release date of WebXR is indefinite a few years under discussion and is not yet parity with the WebVR 1.1 standard from five years back. A-Frame will do its best to smooth out the flux. We may ship an 0.9.1 since WebXR has already broken with Chrome Canary. Biggest things to note for migrating is that:

  • <a-animation> has been removed in favor of the animation component (a back-polyfill exists). We are currently working on fixing some memory leaks in anime.js .
  • Raycaster event APIs have slightly changed.

The Inspector has also received some overhaul with stability, bug fixes, performance improvements, a complete refactoring, UI enhancements, and now a companion server to sync changes back to your HTML files with the A-Frame Watcher!

👀 @aframevr Watcher, a companion to the @aframevr Inspector that can sync changes from the visual editor to your HTML files. Supported on master branch of the Inspector.

Useful for tweaking positions, laying out text w/o going between code + browser. https://t.co/SmTTrljqWA pic.twitter.com/qQxv8KvhQS

— Kevin Ngo (@andgokevin) December 15, 2018

See the release notes or changelog for more details.

What Have People Built?

Let’s check out what people have built how world-renowned companies have released production projects using A-Frame! Also see the new [A-Frame Showcase].

EFF's Spot the Surveillance virtual reality project places you in a street scene, where you learn to identify a variety of police technologies. https://t.co/LuXEJu8atV

🏆🥚 Gunters of OASIS. Hundreds of generated #webvr worlds. Hidden among them a golden egg. Find the egg and inherit the OASIS (and half a hundred dollars). Search for hidden clues, meet up with other Gunters. Ready? Start the hunt on @supermediumvr!https://t.co/oTKimoCrFM pic.twitter.com/jyaPoUGHEW

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) April 4, 2018

I've updated Trajectile Command with a high score leaderboard and a kickin sound track. Try it out on @supermediumvr or another vr browser here: https://t.co/6vL9vyfDSQ … Can you beat my high score?? @aframevr #VR #webvr #webgl pic.twitter.com/vy9oQYaO6K

— Adam Alexander (@AdamAlexandr) June 3, 2018

ð Need someone to talk to? Put on a little show with these cute hand "vuppets" by @jorgefuentesnet! Built with @aframevr #webvr. Now playing on @supermediumvr. pic.twitter.com/UZFHAITWr4

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) November 26, 2018

Numbers

  • 268 contributors with 45 new contributors since March 2018
  • 1,600 total questions asked on StackOverflow
  • 370,000+ people visited aframe.io since March 2018
  • 3,200,000+ pageviews since March 2018
  • Over 9000! GitHub stars
  • 145+ entries of A Week of A-Frame and still going!

What’s Next?

We will ensure that A-Frame runs well on the Oculus Quest, and that there is a place for users to experience A-Frame applications. A-Frame will continue to keep up to date on the WebXR flux. We need to update documentation, guides, and examples. And there are some lingering improvements we want to make to the A-Frame API. Perhaps provide more streamlined tools for A-Frame development.

Thanks to everyone for filing issues, contributing, and sharing your projects!

item.title: A Week of A-Frame 145
item.description:
We’re still working on 0.9.0. Diego is doing lot of testing with the WebXR support which is a lot of work given the flux and discovering issues with the spec, and is triaging through A-Frame issues. We expect it next week. In the meantime, check out this week’s featured projects including the BeatSaver Viewer from us at Supermedium, and usage by Chevrolet!

⚔️ We teamed up w/ the Beat Saber Modding Group & elliotttate to release the open source BeatSaver Viewer! Preview + link community songs on any browser (iOS soon) powered by @aframevr/#webvr. Featured on https://t.co/vj8PxhqxQg!https://t.co/pWKmNRnZdJ https://t.co/eWbcHXuIuz pic.twitter.com/CR4sA8MzKs

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) January 26, 2019

Check out the the all-new 2019 Chevrolet Silverado in 3D! https://t.co/zJ0g7Kadq2 Made with @aframevr & threejs pic.twitter.com/LVZgxxchgx

— Allan Cozart (@ALLANCOZART) January 18, 2019

Slide Puzzle VR - No installs necessary! Play in your web browser.https://t.co/5U0nwXhmkY
for Oculus GO, Gear VR, DayDream, Cardboard, Mobile and PC.#webxr #webvr #html5games #html5 #vr #virtualreality #vrgames #daydream #oculus #gearvr #webgames #onlinegames @aframevr pic.twitter.com/SUsx1c5Vcd

— DS Effects (@dseffects) January 23, 2019

First try of @observablehq (impressed). A little demo of #d3js in #vr using @aframevr - transitions using a custom interpolator. #javascript #webvr pic.twitter.com/krsQ1JcQIW

— Kyran Dale (@kyran_dale) January 22, 2019

  • Wormform - It’s a multi user silicone device that controls a rubber-pipe-thing in 0 gravity room.

Components

  • Shader Buildings - A component that lets you create buildings cheaply enough to put a whole city in your scene
  • glTF Morph Component by elbobo - Control morphTargets in gltf models. These are mesh animations created using shape keys in blender.

Events

@realityvrhack 2019 Pencils down, still waiting for the judges - in the meantime sharing rare @supermediumvr stickers with the folks that truly earned it - big thanks to @PlumCantaloupe for last minute bug fixes @aframevr #WebXR #a11y pic.twitter.com/99KONwDldA

— Roland Dubois (@rolanddubois) January 20, 2019

Dynamically changing textures with #aframe @aframevr in #virtualreality is a nice feature. The cursor will also change to the material the shape changed to. pic.twitter.com/u8TheSDPMX

— Nathan Stevens (@nathantstevens) January 10, 2019

We've done it again! The Camry #WebGL Configurator has won the Visionary Award at the @summitawards for Emerging Media. It's such an honour to be recognised again for this innovative project - try it here: https://t.co/L1HMXwd7cd @aframevr #threejs 🏆🍾🙌 pic.twitter.com/56CkHJeq7l

— Rotor Studios (@rotorstudios) January 11, 2019

Prototype of a virtual tour (e.g. in New York City). Here's the processing pipeline:

1) OSM Overpass API query -> 2) GIS feature extraction -> 3) building reconstruction (#threejs) -> 4) VR composition (@aframevr) -> 5) explore!

Now finalizing 1-3) into a one-stop js lib. pic.twitter.com/hA99jR5c98

— W3Reality (@w3reality) January 17, 2019

Very cool. A #WebVR version of PacMan built using @aframevr https://t.co/Jq1YnvTAJk#VR #PacMan

— Nick Dauchot (@nickuxd) January 8, 2019
